body: Seemed like Travis errored out. @kaspersorensen, can you resubmit request?

Nope I don't control it, INFRA does. But I guess also any new commit will
trigger.

Not sure why Travis complain but LGTM
Merged into the Apache git repo.

Hi Francisco,

All the changes look solid and good to me. But I am a bit concerned about all the cosmetic changes to indentation, line-width etc. etc. 

To your defense, this is not very well guarded or described. But here's my "recipe" that has been used in MetaModel:
1) Make a copy of the defaults in eclipse's java code formatter
2) Change line width from 80 chars to 120 chars
3) Change tabs to spaces (4 spaces)

If you can do that and re-format the classes that you've been working on, then I think we'll have a much prettier diff and thus better be able to track actual changes.
Very good work Alberto! Except for the remarks I've made, I'm very happy with everything I see. If you can attend to those remarks, then I'd certainly give it my +1 :-)

Hey Tomasz,

Not sure if you meant to post this as a pull request and have someone take a look at it? Please also post a few sentences on what this is and what your remarks are... I assume that since the Travis build is still failing on this branch, that you didn't mean for this to get accepted yet? So I'm just asking you to be a bit more verbose :-)

Hi Kasper,

Well, that is surprising. Travis says my branch was build successfully (build 41), but the pull request (build 42 with the same commit) failed. I will look into it. I will also reference the JIRA in the description.

Best regards,
Tomasz

Alberto, I'm sorry if I missed this pull request for some time ... What is the status of it in your opinion? Do you want another review, or are you still working on it, or did you mean for it to be added to MM as is?

Hi Kasper, no worries at all. I worked on the issues that you and Henry opened and they are all fixed/resolved.

IMHO the module is already to be added to MM.
Fixed a test. Now the PR should be ready to be merged.

Looks good to me! Great work Tomasz...

Would you mind doing the merge? Remember to enter "Fixes #4" in the final commit message (that will also close this PR).
Branched out from a different branch, not a master. I will clean it up and publish another pull requst. Sorry.
Looks solid to me. +1

Hi Rafael,

Thank you for the Pull Request! It's great to receive such a contribution. Can you better document if this was a problem before? Maybe create a unittest that would break without the fix and run with the fix? Reason I ask is that there is no reference to a JIRA issue or anything like that, and I was actually under the impression that our parser was not case sensitive, but maybe I was wrong.

Hi Kasper,

I also found the same problem with DISTINCT into lower case. I made some changes to solve it.
I added some test in org.apache.metamodel.query.parser.QueryParserTest that must fail without changes and pass with changes:
- testSelectDistinctInLowerCase()
- testWhereInInLowerCase()
- testWhereLikeInLowerCase()
- testSelectMinInLowerCase()
- testSelectAvgInLowerCase()

Thanks!
Looks good! I'll merge it in :-)
Looks good to me.
Looks good to me. Will you merge it Alberto?
It seems like I do not have write access to the repo in github. Could you sort this out?

Since the GitHub repo is only a mirror, it is not possible actually.

The way it works is a bit lame, but here it is. First take the .diff file from github:

https://github.com/apache/metamodel/pull/9.diff

Then apply this to the regular (apache) git repo. Commit it with a message that says "Fixes #9". You can also have other stuff in the commit message, but this text triggers the close of this PR.
Looks good to me.
Will you merge this one or do you want me to merge it?
Thank you for the explanation Kasper. I will do it ASAP.
Oh please go ahead, I am not working with the MM codebase at the moment so I don't need the context switch ;-)
No worries, I will merge this one as well
Could we add a unittest for this please? There are already a bunch of similar tests in AbstractDataContextTest or maybe it's QueryPostprocessDataContextTest.

yes i'll add unit test as soon as possible.

On Wed, Mar 25, 2015 at 11:23 PM, Kasper SÃ¸rensen notifications@github.com
wrote:

> Could we add a unittest for this please? There are already a bunch of
> similar tests in AbstractDataContextTest or maybe it's
> QueryPostprocessDataContextTest.
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/apache/metamodel/pull/11#issuecomment-86147928.
Hi I have added unit test as you said. Please review
As per leveraging QueryParser, It's not always called. In my example I was testing on the queries with JdbcDataContext and the QueryParser was not called.
Looks good to me. Let's keep it open for others to review for a day or two. If noone sees any issues, I can merge it in for you.

Hi again,

sorry looked another time and in QueryParser (line 158-161) we are instrumenting a QueryPartParser to do the select item parsing ... this is basically what I was referring to. If we use that code we can avoid adding more parsing logic in sparse places like the Query class.

And please correct me if I am wrong, according to my understanding, this QueryParser class is used only when we parse the query passed as a string or executeQuery(String query) of Data context. But if we pass the already constructed query then this class and any parse methods won't be used at all and the functionality fails.

I agree that it is (currently) not being used. But was hoping maybe we could arrange the code so that it will be reused. Your current patch does the job, but I am just affraid that it adds double maintenance of the codebase going forward. If we already have the "comma and parenthesis parsing" in place in QueryPartParser, then maybe we can reuse it.
oh.. okay then.. I'll look into it
Hey I have used the QueryPartParser and SelectItemParser as you said. And it's working great.
Cool, then I'll finally merge it ;-) Thanks for the contribution and your patience.
I thought returning the same reference might prove risky and have unexpected behavior. But yes, what you said makes sense.

Yes normally I would also be in favor of making a copy. But in this case it is really a "reference" and not an independent item. So if you change that then I think we can make the general change a lot less - then you don't need to make the clone method public and you don't need to change the existing unittest.
No that existing unit test still changes because the alias name in query will be replaced by <tablename>.<columnName>.i.e. "foobarbaz" gets replaced by "a.foo"
Anyhow I'll make that change you suggested
Hi, I have made the change to return same item instead of clone.
Fine I'll remove that getAllSelectItems() method but isn't subquery in from and where class there in to do list of MetaModel. I remember seeing it in jira for improvement.

SELECT... FROM (SELECT name as n FROM ...) as q where n='foo';  is perfectly valid but will fail if we don't consider select items of other clauses if and when we support sub queries for from and where clause in MetaModel.

Hey, I noticed one thing just now. We can actually use subqueries in from clause at least for JdbcDataContext. Below is the query I ran which was successful.

Query query = dataContext.parse("SELECT password as X from (select username,password from AMASS_USER)  S");
Correct, that's the one type of subquery we support. One that is in the FROM clause. We don't support it in select or where (currently).

I believe that where clause will only work on JDBC because it gets carried along as one big expression. But MM unfortunately will not understand it so no select items will be there anyway. Hmm how about then making a getSelectItemByAlias(...) method. We could start with just items from SELECT but could eventually expand it if subquery support increases.
Ya.. that sounds like a good plan.. I'll make the necessary changes and commit it today
Committed with recommended changes...

Thanks for the patch, but I don't think this approach will fly. First I have to mention that there are code styling issues (tabs instead of spaces, no spaces in front of parenthesis etc.) but that's less important right now ...

Important part is: Different databases have different SQL dialects and in this patch it is proposed to switch from one dialect (that was very common but less flexible) to the other dialect which is AFAIK less supported.

Here's some sources of inspiration maybe:

[1] http://www.w3schools.com/sql/sql_primarykey.asp
[2] http://www.techonthenet.com/sql/primary_keys.php

To make this work we should only touch the JdbcCreateTableBuilder IMO. The abstract one is not supposed/guaranteed to generate perfect SQL for all databases, just like Query.toSql() will not generate SQL that is working on all databases. It is in the concrete implementation of CreateTableBuilder that we figure that part out (and in non-JDBC modules it is not a CREATE TABLE statement but some other operation anyway).

The JdbcCreateTableBuilder should take advice or delegate to the QueryRewriter interface. This is our current mechanism to allow different databases to have different dialects. I suggest we continue with that approach unless there's some better idea.

Yes, what you said is true. But the reason I thought of above fix is, all the databases METAMODEL supports have a same syntax for creating table. So It would be unnecessary overhead writing like QueryRewriter(Different databases have slightly different Query syntax). 

Is there any such database with different create table syntax?

OK maybe that's the case - I didn't think so because of the above articles. When you say "all databases MetaModel supports", do you then include the ones that are not included in the (non-integration) tests?
- PostgreSQL
- MS SQL Server
- Oracle
- MySQL
- IBM DB2

Those are needed to work.

Do we have a test case to ensure that the new syntax is working (see JdbcTestTemplates which is used for most unit and integration tests).

Yes, above databases also have same syntax. 

And as for unit test cases, I have already committed it(DerbyTest and h2DatabaseTest with create table check). Is it enough?
oops.. sorry.. didn't see that.. I'll correct it :)

OK let's then just take attention to the small code styling thingies :) Once done I will do a round of integration tests locally (not covered by Travis CI) so that I feel certain about giving it my +1 ;-)
Hey, I made the formatting as discussed.
There's also a minor unittest failure now due to the comma-related change.
Ya..  I have changed it now along with the unit tests.

My integration-test verification progress:
- [x] PostgreSQL
- [x] MySQL
- [x] DB2
- [x] SQL Server
- [x] Oracle
Looks good! I will commit it with an addition of a bunch of integration tests :-)
Oh right, we should update that :)

Hi Rafael,

Thank you for the contribution, really appreciate the work. I am aware of the issue but I think this solution is a bit too fragile. It only reads the first line to determine the data type and it also does type casting/narrowing on each single value instead of trying to establish a data type and only narrow according to that type. That essentially means that as a user I have no guarantee that row 1 is going to have the same data types as row 2. That feels very unsafe to me at least. I could effectively have a table with e.g. column type NUMBER which would make sense on the first row but on the second row I would get a String or something completely different.
I am closing this and creating a new pull request with responses to all the review comments.
I am not sure why the build failed on the CI server, since it builds fine on my dev. environment.
Trying to fix the CI failure

For the future: You don't need to close the Pull Requests just because you have changes. The moment you commit new code to the branch then the existing PR is automatically updated. Closing it and opens a new one is a bit troublesome for the reviewers because we loose track of existing remarks.

My 5 cents:
- I like the approach you've taken here with the compound from items array.
- But shouldn't we rather then take a step further and delete the "leftItem" and "rightItem" and let the array replace them.
- Similarly I would expect an array for the "on items" then. And then delete the "leftOn" and "rightOn" fields.
- Then you would no longer need "_isCompoundJoin" - it would always be a (compound) join if there is an array available.

Alternative approach is to keep FromItem as it is and just apply the nested FromItem structure when parsing the query. That would retain 100% backwards compatibility and only do something in the query parsing layer to fix the issue. Might also be an option.

Hi,

I looked into the points you mentioned above. Below are my thoughts.
1. We actually need "leftItem" and "rightItem" as we even use it in compound from items ultimately, since it's the only way to represent join. 
2. "on items" are indeed array of select items and for each from item we need them seperately since there might be other operations than "=".
3. I didn't try about nested from items but it needs code change more than this. Moreover with this approach we are using existing code which is both unit tested and time tested.
4. This doesn't cause any api changes either as there is no change in signature of any public method.
And any idea why travis ci build failed. It ran perfectly fine while I unit tested it. Could it be because of other PRs pending?
And sorry no I don't know why Travis failed ... Seemed to happen in the elasticsearch module which normally works fine. Can you try a local build?
But if we use multiple joins as above wouldn't it cause problem in case let's say there is a column with name "key2" in both table1 and table2?
It's a bit beyond my memory actually... Let me say it like this: I think it works because I am not aware of any bugs in that regard :-)

I agree, we should be using replaceAll instead of replace but I think we need to keep the if in the turnOperandIntoRegExp method to prepend "^" when the like operand is like "MALE%" (pick up just elements starting with MALE). If we remove this condition we will pick up ALWAYS every string with the MALE substring in it and this is not what we want.
Changes suggested by @LosD implemented. Thank you again!
Minor issue left, but looks good to me! :)
Minor issue addressed. ping @LosD
Looks super! Let's merge it.
Though Travis seems to have failed?
Okay, seems unrelated (ElasticSearch). @kaspersorensen also mentioned that we have had Travis problems with ES, so still good :)
Yes, not sure what's going on with Travis but I've seen some builds of the PR "green"
I'm pretty sure it's not a problem; both Java 7 & 8 completes successfully, and (much unlike the ES code) there is nothing in this code that should be affected by the JDK version.
Looks good, I'll push it.

Sorry that was a lot of nitty gritty details. I am just trying to show that implementing executeQuery(...) is very complex because the Query object is complex. I really think that you/we should start with just "the simplest thing that works" and then work our way from there. First make it work, then make it fast.

Thank you for the detailed comments. I concur in part - some corner cases may need handling. Some kinds of queries, such as joins are rarely used in Solr and the support is inefficient.

if executeQuery() is not implemented, then is there any other method which makes sense to implement? If not, do you recommend deferring the release of this till all corner cases are handled? 

The module is almost useless if the actual search does not take place in the engine itself, as users would generally use search engines for large data sets, which practically cannot be read into the MetaModel application space and searched in the MM layer. Hence, I was wondering if it has to be a all or nothing approach and if we could throw exceptions for unsupported query patterns and incrementally handle the rare query patterns too.

Do let me know your thoughts.

Hi,

I have used nested from item structure as you suggested. And yes there was very less code change :) Please review

The reason I'm passing array+instance of from item is, the instance is we know for sure right side item. If we just pass set(including right side item), there will be n square combinations we need to check. Or am I wrong?
Done with my review. Only minor remarks really. The only one that I am a little bit concerned with is the parenthesis hiding approach. This seems to maybe be too destructive.

Hi,

the reason for removing alias for onSelectItem(side Alias) is let's say we have a query like below:

Query query = context.parse("Select a.col2 from A a INNER JOIN B b ON a.col1 = b.col2 INNER JOIN C c ON a.col3 = c.col3");

If we parse it by replacing sideAlias of select Item then it gets translated as below:

"SELECT a.col2 from A a INNER JOIN B b on a.col1 = b.col2 INNER JOIN C c ON b.col3 = c.col3"
which is wrong and results in SQLException

And the reason I put that condition for only leftFromItem is since we parse from left to right, only left from item can have composite join. Can you think of a scenario where even rightFromItem can be composite. If so I will add that also.

Hi Ashish,

I know that doing a JOIN is pretty unusual in "normal" mode of Solr. But in my opinion we are also not catering to the normal cases. MetaModel exposes an API that is useful especially because it is the _same_ API across all datastores. That means our users often use MetaModel in scenarios where they might just as well use a relational database or an Excel sheet as the backing store. The benefit they get with MetaModel is that their code to process data can run on any given datastore. That means the type of use is often pretty untypical. So having support for JOIN in Solr is actually pretty important in my opinion. I would even go as far as to say that effeciency in execution is secondary to compatibility with the API. Reason being that if people are trying to get the most performance out of their Solr system then they will anyways be going directly to Solr's primary API.

That said I do believe that there are scenarios you absolutely should support.

My suggestion is just that you start small and get something that functionally fulfills the whole API. Then expand on a case-by-case basis to add optimized support for various classes of queries. For instance you can start with just materializeMainSchemaTable - make it work without any default limits or anything like that. And make sure that it is cursor based so that you don't load a million records into memory but rather maintain a cursor in the dataset implementation.

Once that is working I would expand the scope to also have support for COUNT queries. And then maybe queries with just a single WHERE item. And so on and so on ... Makes sense?

The right item way is also possible because anyone can build such a query programmatically. In our use of MetaModel we mostly do that and don't use the parser. A bit cumbersome, but allows different components to influence the query plan that we have as a kind application of the visitor pattern.

I don't think I understand what you're saying about the side alias... I honestly also cannot remember all the nitty gritty details ... Just feel that it's a bit dangerous to throw that alias away - it could be referred to elsewhere I guess.

We are definitely not getting rid of alias. Instead we are using the select item as is. i.e. select item column name or expression along with its alias. In the unit test case you can see all aliases present.
And I have done that change of passing entire set and will push it today.
Looks good to me.
Feel free to push Alberto :)
I've just pushed to our "main" repo. Both the PR and the jira issue haven't been closed though (I've included the text "This closes #METAMODEL-138" in the last commit)
